render.tex: \title{Completing the squares} Being able to do the following conversion\small\[ \quad ax^2 + bx + c \longrightarrow a\cdot \left(x + \alpha \right)^2 \pm \beta^2 \]\normalsize

reason.tex:
%text \underline\text{Any quadratic polynomial} $ax^2 + bx + c$ can be rewritten as \[ \qquad a\cdot \left(x + \alpha \right)^2 + \beta^2\quad \left(a \neq 0 \right)\] Here is how % \begin{align}
ax^2 &+ bx + c = a\cdot \left[x^2 + \frac{b}{a} x + \frac{c}{a} \right] \\ &= a\cdot \left[\underbrace{x^2 + 2\frac{b}{2a}\cdot x + \left(\frac{b}{2a} \right)^2}_{\text{Look familiar?}} + \frac{c}{a} - \left(\frac{b}{2a} \right)^2 \right] \\ &= a\cdot \left(x + \frac{b}{2a} \right)^2 + \left(c-\frac{b^2}{4a} \right) \\ &\implies \alpha = \left(\frac{b}{2a} \right)\text{ and } \beta = \left(c-\frac{b^2}{4a} \right) \end{align} %text Completing the squares is a \underline\text{very handy trick} You will find it especially useful when evaluating integrals of quadratic polynomials%
